- The Procurement shall coordinate with the Finance to ensure sufficient approved budget exists for the purchase requisition. B
- The Procurement Practitioners responsible for managing categories shall receive the purchase requisition after it has been approved in the Procurement Gate. They shall perform an initial check for completeness and take the necessary action for Purchase Order creation. In particular, stock availability must be checked before raising an order. C.
- The purchase requisitions processed by the Procurement may require further approval as per the PDoA. D.

metadata.context: This chunk elaborates on the definition and governance of Purchase Orders, confirming that Procurement is the sole authorized function to create and issue orders, and that each line item must be categorized according to the established Category Hierarchy, reinforcing controls and accountability within the requisition-to-pay process.

nodes.text:
- The  Purchase  Order  is  a  written  contract  between  the  government  entity  and  Suppliers  to procure goods, services and projects in reference to the Contract or the Price List Agreement or on a standalone basis. The Procurement is the only function allowed to create and issue orders to Suppliers. A
- Every line item in the Purchase Order shall be assigned to one of the categories following the Category Hierarchy. B

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the core principles and procedural requirements for creating Purchase Orders, including validation of purchase requisitions, supplier selection, term negotiation, and mandatory creation through the Procurement Gate before supplier commitment, as specified in the procurement process on Page 53.

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall adhere to the following principles when creating an order:
- C1. Determine  need  based  on  the  purchase  requisition  and  prepare  specifications  to communicate with Suppliers
- C2. Select Supplier
- C3. Negotiate appropriate business terms, if not already in place
- C4. Agree on delivery terms and conditions
- C5. Agree on payment terms
- C6. Ensure necessary terms and conditions are put in place in the order itself or the underlying contract
- C7. Ensure purchase requisition exists and has been approved in the Procurement Gate
- The Procurement shall create Purchase Orders through the Procurement Gate. The Purchase Order must be created before committing to a Supplier. D .

metadata.context: This chunk emphasizes that Purchase Orders must be approved through the Procurement Gate according to the PDoA before release to suppliers, ensuring alignment with authority thresholds and preventing unauthorized order issuance.

nodes.text: - The  Purchase  Order  shall  be  released  by  the  Procurement  to  the  Supplier  only  after  due approvals  have  been  obtained  from  appropriate  authorities  as  established  in  the  PDoA.  No Purchase Orders shall be released without approvals granted in the Procurement Gate. A

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the rules for creating Purchase Orders for non-exempt goods, services, and projects, and specifies mandatory guidelines for exempted items, including the use of exception codes, invoice validation, and end-user suggestion verification, as defined in the procurement process on Page 53.

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall create Purchase Orders for purchasing of all goods, services and projects unless the goods, services and projects are a part of the exemption list approved as per the PDoA. A
- At the minimum, the following guidelines shall be adhered to while placing orders with Suppliers for exempted goods, services and projects: B
- B1. The Procurement shall provide the Supplier with a Valid Exception Code to quote on its invoice instead of the Purchase Order number.
- B2. The  Procurement  shall  ensure  the  Finance  returns  invoices  not  having  Purchase  Order number nor exemption code to the Supplier.
- B3. The Procurement shall be responsible for verifying and adding goods, services and projects suggested by the End-users.

metadata.context: This chunk outlines permitted scenarios under which the Procurement function can amend a Purchase Order, specifically when there is a quantity variance between the purchase requisition and the order, as defined in the procurement process on Page 54. It is part of a broader set of rules governing Purchase Order modifications, including value thresholds and approval requirements.

nodes.text:
- The Procurement may amend the Purchase Order at the minimum for the following scenarios: A
- A1. When  the  quantity  in  a  Purchase  Order  is  different  than  the  quantity  in  a  purchase requisition.

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the conditions and restrictions for amending a Purchase Order, including value variances, supplier delays, approval thresholds, and project-specific amendments, as specified in the procurement guidelines on Page 54.

nodes.text:
- A2. When the value of a Purchase Order is different than the approved value of a purchase requisition.
- The Procurement shall not amend the Purchase Order to accommodate the Supplier's delays in executing the scope of work unless some action or instruction from the government entity has caused or contributed to such a delay. B
- When  the  variance  to  the  original  contracted  price  exceeds  the  approved  threshold,  the Procurement shall require approval from the appropriate authority as per the PDoA, for the total of the original agreement and the exceeded variation. C.
- The Procurement shall not require approval for amendment if the value between the purchase requisition  and  the  Purchase  Order  is  within  the  defined  Tolerances  to  accommodate  for differences in the estimated value in the purchase requisition and the actual value based on pricing agreed with the Supplier. D.
- The Procurement while amending the Purchase Order for the procurement of projects shall verify the agreement of the End-user of the project and if necessary consult with the Tendering Committee. The amendment shall not be issued to accomplish work outside the original business case or plan. E

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the conditions and procedural requirements for cancelling a Purchase Order, specifying when cancellation is justified (e.g., unneeded items, scope changes, delivery failures) and emphasizing that cancellation in the Procurement Gate must follow the cancellation of the underlying purchase requisition with proper approvals as per the PDoA. It appears on Page 54, following sections on order amendments and preceding emergency purchasing rules.

nodes.text:
- The  Procurement  shall  initiate  the  cancellation  of  the  Purchase  Order  under  the  following scenarios: A
- A1. When goods, services and projects are not anymore needed by the requestor
- A2. When goods, services and projects change in specification or scope
- A3. When a Supplier is unable to deliver goods, services and projects as per the agreed delivery conditions
- The  Procurement  shall  cancel  the  Purchase  Order  in  the  Procurement  Gate  only  after  the purchase requisition is cancelled by the requestor after approvals as per PDoA. B

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the authorized scenarios for emergency purchasing, as defined in the procurement process, and is located on Page 54, following the procedures for purchase order amendments and cancellations. It specifies that emergency purchases require PDoA approval and are limited to operational or personal emergencies involving immediate risks to operations, safety, or health.

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall allow emergency purchasing after approval as per PDoA, in the following situations: A
- A1. Operational  emergency  -  immediate  disruption  of  operations  resulting  in  significant expense or liability for the government entity, or critical systems are down, or when other assets  and  the  environment  are  under  serious  threat  and  need  to  be  addressed immediately.
- A2. Personal  emergency  -  immediate  danger  to  human  safety  and  health  that  need  to  be addressed immediately.

metadata.context: This chunk discusses the rules and responsibilities surrounding emergency purchases, including their exception status, documentation requirements, and the need to prevent misuse as a substitute for proper planning. It appears on Page 55 and aligns with emergency purchasing procedures outlined in the document, specifically under the emergency purchase exceptions and end-user accountability.

nodes.text:
- An emergency purchase is an exception process, and it may be utilised only to purchase what is necessary to cover the emergency. Emergency purchases are not permitted under any other circumstances. B
- The Procurement shall ensure that the End-users do not use emergency purchase as an excuse for failing to plan. All emergency purchases must be documented in the Procurement Gate and shall be closely scrutinised and reported by the Procurement. C.

metadata.context: This chunk addresses the creation and requirements for post factum Purchase Orders when purchases or supplier commitments occur without prior authorization through the Procurement Gate, emphasizing that such orders are mandatory for non-exempt goods, services, and projects and must follow proper purchase requisition approval as per PDoA. It appears on Page 55, alongside rules on emergency purchases and receiving procedures.

headings: 13.13. Managing Receiving of Goods, Services and Projects

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall create post factum Purchase Order when goods, services and projects have been purchased, or commitment to Supplier has been given without authorisation through the Procurement Gate. The post factum Purchase Orders shall be required for all goods, services and projects not a part of the exempted list. A
- The Procurement shall create a post factum Purchase Order only after the purchase requisition has been created with justification and approved by the appropriate authority as per the PDoA. B

headings: 13.13. Managing Receiving of Goods, Services and Projects
metadata.context: This chunk outlines the procedures for receiving goods, services, and projects, including physical receiving, inspection and acceptance/rejection, recording in the Procurement Gate, verification against delivery notes, inspection criteria, and timely recording—aligning with the broader procurement process on pages 54–55.

nodes.text:
- The Procurement in coordination with the End-user and other relevant parties shall ensure the receiving of goods, services and projects which at the minimum shall include: A
- A1. Physical receiving
- A2. Inspection and acceptance or rejection
- A3. Recording in the Procurement Gate
- The  delivery  note  concerning  Purchase  Order  shall  be  created  by  the  Supplier  for  all  goods, services  and  projects  delivered.  The  Procurement  shall  ensure  that  the  End-users  perform receipt against the delivery note immediately after delivery, and any discrepancies or damages are recorded. B
- The Procurement shall ensure that the inspection of goods, services and projects is performed by the receiving End-users or subject matter experts responsible for undertaking this task. The inspection shall focus on the quantity and quality of the received goods, services and projects. It shall determine conformance to the acceptance criteria, requirements and terms and conditions of the Purchase Order taking into consideration the Tolerances. C.
- The Procurement shall ensure that received goods, executed services and projects are recorded in the Procurement Gate without unnecessary delay. If a partial delivery is made a partial receipt shall be entered. D.

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the Procurement's responsibilities regarding supplier returns, including initiation by End-users, validation, coordination, communication, credit assurance, and recording of return details, and is situated on Page 56 of the document.

headings: 13.13. Managing Receiving of Goods, Services and Projects

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall manage returns to Suppliers and ensure receiving appropriate credit for the  return.  Returns  shall  be  driven  by  the  need  repair  or  replace  goods  or  non-conforming services and projects. A
- The Procurement shall ensure the End-users initiate and request formally for the returns. B
- The Procurement shall be responsible for: C
- C1. Validation of the requests to return
- C2. Coordination of necessary arrangements with the Supplier to obtain a return authorisation
- C3. Arrangement of returns
- C4. Communication with Suppliers and the End-users
- C5. Ensure receiving appropriate credit for the returns
- C6. Recording the return transaction details including the reason for returns

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the Procurement's responsibilities in managing disputes related to goods, including specific scenarios like shortage, non-conformance, and damage, and details the process of receiving disputes, verifying claims, notifying suppliers, and facilitating supplier disputes. It is located on Page 56 and forms part of the broader procurement dispute management process.

headings: 13.16. Disputes Related to Services and Projects Purchasing

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall manage all disputes raised by the End-users not limited to the following scenarios: A
- A1. Goods shortage
- A2. Goods not as per required specification
- A3. Substitute goods which have not been authorised or approved
- A4. Goods not conforming to technical specifications
- A5. Goods not as per required shelf life
- A6. Damaged goods
- The Procurement shall ensure receiving the communication about dispute from the End-users. The Procurement shall verify the claims for compensation and may seek advice from the Finance and the Legal if required. The Procurement shall send the notification to the Supplier to replace or provide reimbursement for the goods. B
- If the Supplier raises a dispute to the claim, the Procurement shall facilitate dispute resolution with the Supplier. C.

headings: 13.16. Disputes Related to Services and Projects Purchasing
metadata.context: This chunk outlines the scenarios under which End-users must raise disputes for services and projects, aligning with the broader dispute management framework on pages 56 and 57, where disputes related to goods are similarly defined and resolved. It specifies that disputes must cover failure to perform or fulfil contractual obligations, property loss/damage, or non-conformance to contract terms, and follows the same resolution process as goods-related disputes.

headings: 13.16. Disputes Related to Services and Projects Purchasing

nodes.text:
- The  Procurement  shall  ensure  that  the  End-users  raise  disputes  for  services  and  projects purchases covering but not limited to the following scenarios: A
- A1. Failure to perform or fulfil contractual obligations

headings: 13.16. Disputes Related to Services and Projects Purchasing
metadata.context: This chunk appears on Page 57 under the section "The Procurement shall ensure that the End-users raise disputes for services and projects purchases," specifying scenarios for service and project disputes and stating that such disputes are resolved similarly to goods disputes. It follows the broader context of dispute management for both goods and services, aligning with the procurement responsibilities outlined in the document.

headings: 13.16. Disputes Related to Services and Projects Purchasing

nodes.text:
- A2. Relate to the loss of or damage to property
- A3. Non-conformance to terms and conditions of the contract
- Disputes related to services and projects shall be resolved similarly as disputes related to goods. B

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the Procurement's responsibility in managing the requisition-to-pay cycle, including ensuring timely and accurate payment release to suppliers based on approved purchase orders and contractual terms, with Finance authorized to release payments as per specified payment terms. It is situated on Page 57, which also details payment verification requirements and escalation procedures for late or missing payments.

headings: 13.16. Disputes Related to Services and Projects Purchasing

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall be responsible for the execution of requisition to pay cycle. A
- The Finance shall be authorised for releasing payment to Suppliers. The invoice shall be paid according to the payment terms specified in the order or contract it refers to. B

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the Procurement's responsibilities in facilitating timely and accurate supplier payments, including adherence to contractual obligations, receipt verification in the Procurement Gate, payment terms, budget limits, and documentation requirements, and escalation of late or missing payments to the Chairman of the government entity. It is situated on Page 57, following the discussion on dispute management and preceding the definitions of procurement-related terms on Page 58.

nodes.text:
- The Procurement shall facilitate the release of payments to the Suppliers in a timely and accurate manner  upon  verification  of  required  documentation.  The  Procurement  shall  escalate  late payment and missing payments to the Chairman of the government entity. A
- The  Procurement  while  facilitating  the  release  of  payment  to  Suppliers,  shall  adhere  to  the following: B
- B1. Purchase Order is approved and executed as per the agreed contractual obligations
- B2. The goods, services or projects invoiced must be received, accepted and recorded in the Procurement Gate
- B3. Payments shall be made as per payment terms specified in the order or contract
- B4. Payment  value  shall  not  exceed  the  amount  specified  in  the  Purchase  Order  or  its amendments considering the Tolerances specified in the contract
- B5. Payments shall be made only if relevant supporting documents are attached and verified

metadata.context: This chunk defines key terms and concepts within the procurement framework, providing clear definitions for essential components such as the Procurement Framework, Standards, Charter, Delegation of Authority, Manual, Gate, and key roles like Procurement Practitioners and End-users. It is situated on Page 58 and serves as a foundational reference for understanding the terminology and structure used throughout the procurement process, particularly in relation to responsibilities, governance, and operational procedures detailed on Pages 57 and 59.

nodes.text: Procurement Framework, 1 = A set of interrelated documents devised to help procurement professionals in their work.. Procurement Standards, 1 = An integrated set of principles that harmonise the way of working, establish a unified operating model and define the performance of the Procurement.. Procurement Charter, 1 = A formal document defining the roles and committees required for the procurement operations.. Procurement Delegation of Authority, 1 = A formal document defining division of authority and powers in the government entity related to procurement operations.. Procurement Manual, 1 = A reference document that defines the common and compliant execution of procurement activities for the procurement function of the government entity, in alignment with the Procurement Standards.. Procurement Gate, 1 = An information technology platform of the Procurement, including a portal for internal and external users.. Chairman of the government entity, 1 = Chairman, Board of Directors or equivalent, in charge of governance of the government entity.. Procurement, 1 = The procurement function existing within or outside the government entity.. Procurement Practitioners, 1 = Employees of the government entity involved in procuring or making procurement decisions on behalf of the government entity.. Financial Interest, 1 = Financial benefits such as income, honoraria or equity in the form of stock, stock options or other ownership rights and royalties or payments received by the Procurement Practitioner or his/her spouse, dependants and relatives limited to the second degree of relations.. End-users, 1 = The requesters or requesting parties of goods, services and projects.. Finance, 1 = The function within the government entity dedicated to financial affairs.. Legal, 1 = The function within the government entity dedicated to legal affairs.

metadata.context: This chunk defines key procurement terms and concepts on pages 59 and 60, expanding on definitions from the procurement framework by specifying roles (e.g., Procurement Committee, Tendering Committee), strategic plans (e.g., Procurement Function Plan), performance metrics (e.g., Key Performance Indicator), cost outcomes (e.g., Savings), and tendering methods (e.g., Public Tender, Sole Source Tender). It provides essential terminology for understanding procurement governance, operations, and decision-making processes within government entities.

nodes.text: Procurement Committee, An individual or an organisation registered in the Procurement Gate and licensed to supply the goods, services or projects. = A committee responsible for supervising the procurement function that is appointed by the Chairman of the government entity.. Tendering Committee, An individual or an organisation registered in the Procurement Gate and licensed to supply the goods, services or projects. = A committee established to evaluate the results of relevant tenders and encourage cross-functional collaboration.. Procurement Function Plan, An individual or an organisation registered in the Procurement Gate and licensed to supply the goods, services or projects. = Annual internal plan of the procurement function detailing the outcomes and outputs derived from the procurement strategy, with assigned internal budget and relevant performance measures.. Procurement Management Report, An individual or an organisation registered in the Procurement Gate and licensed to supply the goods, services or projects. = A report issued by the head of the Procurement to report the performance of the procurement function.. Key Performance Indicator, An individual or an organisation registered in the Procurement Gate and licensed to supply the goods, services or projects. = A quantifiable measure used to evaluate the success of the government entity or employee in meeting performance objectives.. metadata.context: This chunk defines key procurement terms related to bidding, awards, agreements, and transactional documentation, primarily found on Page 60 of the document. It supplements definitions from Page 59 by providing specific, actionable terms used in procurement processes, enhancing search retrieval for concepts like bid bonds, purchase orders, and intellectual property.

nodes.text: Bid Bonds, 1 = A guarantee required for the bidding process to mitigate bidding risks. A bid bond ensures that the awarded Supplier will fulfil the commitments of the accepted bid.. Single Award, 1 = An award made to one Supplier.. Split Award, 1 = An award made to every selected Supplier for each part of a divided solicitation.. Primary and Secondary Award, 1 = A type of award where in addition to the selected primary source award is also made to a secondary or backup source of supply.. Multiple Awards, 1 = Awards madetomultiple sources of supply for the samematerials, services and projects.. Price List Agreement, 1 = A type of framework agreement for establishing the terms governing contracts to be awarded during a given period, in particular with regard to the price of goods, services and projects.. Performance Bonds, 1 = A guarantee issued to provide security for satisfactory completion of a contract. A performance bond ensures payment of a sum of money in case of a failure of a Supplier to meet obligations specified in the contract.. Intellectual Property, 1 = Rights or property owned by an individual or organisation or the government entity and legally protected from unauthorised use. Intellectual property may consist of but is not limited to patents, trade secrets, copyrights and trademarks or simply ideas.. Background Intellectual Property, 1 = Intellectual Property that is relevant to the procured goods, services or projects, supplied by the contracting parties at the beginning of the engagement.. Foreground Intellectual Property, 1 = Intellectual Property created during the tenure and framework of the contract between the contracting parties.. Purchase Order, 1 = A legally binding document issued by the government entity to Suppliers in reference to the Contract or the Price List Agreement or on a standalone basis, indicating key parameters of purchase such as quantities, agreed prices, delivery schedule, payment terms and other relevant information and committing both parties upon explicit or implicit confirmation by Supplier.. Valid Exception Code, 1 = Acodegiven to goods, services and projects for which post factum Purchase Orders are allowed to be issued.. Payment Terms, 1 = Terms that specify the period and modality of payment to the Supplier.

Tolerances, 1 = Acceptable variations in price, quantity and physical parameters of delivered goods.. Dispute Resolution, 1 = Mechanism of resolving disputes between contracting parties..
